Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp Pad Thai

E0XbV8wcJxmMIjWxFG1KOg.text: First time visit Pittsburgh. I felt like having some noodles and just saw the place. The restaurant is clean, price okay, and the staff are friendly. They serve food pretty quickly. The only negative thing is they offered me the wrong dish. I wanted pho with beef, but it was ramen with chicken, #NotEvenClose :0.  But I had it anyway. The ramen is much better than the average. At that time I thought they either run out of pho and chicken or they were just careless. Wait! How can a restaurant run out of beef? So now I am praying that the food is not from some previous order or somewhere more gross.  I would rate 4 stars for the ramen. Take one star out for the mistake. The most disgusting part is all my guess, so it would be unfair to be considered. But not going again.

MfqknBKZ15FJb2Vn1kNeOQ.text: This place is full of memories for me from my summer days as a Govie at Carnegie Mellon!  The prices are great, the portions are very generous, the service is fast and friendly, and the food itself is quality Americanized Asian Fusion.  And by that, I mean that they have everything from pad thai to crab rangoons to Taiwanese beef noodle soup to chow fun.  I like to stick to my seafood pan-fried Hong Kong noodles with a crab rangoon appetizer, chased down with a taro bubble tea.  Yeah, I know, super healthy.  But it's filling, cheap, and great for CMU students.  Oh wait, I guess I don't have the metabolism of a college student anymore...oops...

dX-VAUQo6NiI1F7JxeAZHw.text: Lulus is one of my favorite restaurants... definitely underrated Asian and I've been going here since I was a kid. A Pittsburgh staple! However my favorite dish Singapore rice noodles was just taken off the menu. I'm so upset by this because I order it every time and it's delicious!!! Please bring it back Lulus.

IQf_gW0qJgTSTYrZGnby3Q.text: Not very impressed.  Hyped up fast food chinese restaurant, American style.  Food is average, price is higher with no service.   The lady in the front is a bit up tight, makes our ordering experience a little awkward.

qteW6EBky_I-LTy7MCn8RQ.text: I stopped for a snack and ordered iced tea,cold sesame noodles and 2 egg rolls.  The tea was stale and undrinkable,  the egg rolls tasted spoiled  and the noodles tasted as if they had been cooked days ago and stored In a cardboard box.  This the last time I ever eat there.  Just awful

7Q3eQx-U8W0ORotq0Ihwig.text: I ordered Kung Pao chicken which is one of my favorite Chinese dishes. The  vegetables were fresh & abundant and the chicken was properly cooked. However, the meal was utterly bland and completely lacking in soul. The boba tea wasn't bad though it did have a bit too much ice. Service was the bright part of this dining experience - my waiter was quite efficient and polite.

8Y-unfD_2gVs5cn3wj4KMA.text: Good food at reasonable price. Not quite sure why it is rated so poorly. I have been there a couple of times, and the service has been pretty good.

pp-ypuI953hW8aon5VzbkQ.text: Some of the awesomest and tastiest Asian fusion around! Love coming here with my boyfriend to just talk and hang out, enjoying choices from a variety of fulfilling dishes at good prices. I would liken Lulu's to a busy coffee shop where you can get some good Asian eats. I always get the curry with tofu, which is absolutely delicious - lending veggies and spice to my taste buds! The pad Thai is also very good. A fun atmosphere also to be enjoyed with teas/smoothies!

1hQFDM_BU1EpVoVCgvJ-Xw.text: I've been coming here for over ten years.  Lulu's is Lulu's and it will never change but fortunately their Fried Tofu (big plate), hot and sour soup, and crab rangoon have never changed, and neither has my love of very unhealthy fried food.  if you come here for dinner the service is terrible but you'll get your food eventually.  if you come here for lunch your food will come out very quick and extremely hot, and it may or may not arrive around the same time your dining companion's food arrives.  it's cheap.  it's greasy.  the spicy peanut noodle bowl is DELISH. So is the fried tofu, egg roll, hot and sour soup, crab rangoon, curry, and pad thai.

8zjO4yju2ipwDNETb8x4Kw.text: This was my first time eating at Lulu's Noodles.  I wasn't aware of the fact that you need to get money from the ATM if you plan on buying a meal using your credit card for under $10.00.  I should have checked the insider tips beforehand.  I had to wait in a longer line, but eventually I got my food.  I was looking for a dish with more vegetables, but the lady at the register told me that the Pad Tai and Chicken Curry dish had an equal amount of vegetables.  It would have been an extra $2.00 to get an additional vegetables, so I thought I would pass.  I ended up getting the Chicken Pad Tai, which I thought overall it was decent, but I've eaten better Pad Tai at a different restaurant.  If I come back here, I'm going to be prepared with cash on hand and will be looking for a chicken dish with more vegetables.

iuoTdWP0l5RfnuODXcBjmQ.text: great tasting food right across from the museum. walk right in, fast service,

K2kc8MHJX8idYCbwyr6Jlg.text: A group of us came here after a workout. I thought the prices were reasonable, and the the service was fast! Waitress was on top of drink refills etc.

AhWU27OUCMmiBPNlTpKp9Q.text: Good place for a quick, inexpensive lunch. We both had ramen, I chose the spicy one. Both were good, but I liked mine better, and it wasn't remotely spicy; I'd have to add sriracha on a cold day. The server suggested pork with mine, and it was good, but next time, I think I'll try a vegetable ramen. There will definitely be a next time, though.

nATT0TaXrHLjtpF_WCCbgg.text: Lulu's is my go to comfort food spot for slightly above average Americanized Asian food. I like the Fried Tofu and spring rolls, it's always a ton of food so I get to take leftovers home. The bubble tea definitely isn't as good as it used to be, I would skip getting bubble tea here and pop into Rose's down the street instead for that. But if you want simple comfort food Lulu's is the place. Note that for lunch it's cafeteria style - order at counter, get a number and sit. For dinner it's still regular service.

unjco9HN_roFXLFrrhYCwA.text: I came here with friends and school librarian and the food is pretty good. I don't know much about Chinese food or whatever but for being a picky eater, the chicken lo mein is really good.

lxu4ZE8zidOlqIxZR9gdtA.text: Tasty, large portions and inexpensive.  It's hard not to love LuLu's noodles and every sauce that comes with them.  General Tso's chicken was amAzing!   Mayne Not the most adventurous  item on the menu but everyone needs a little spicy sauce'd chicken to munch on once in a while!  The customer service was friendly and fast.   Also perfect with the fortune which read "you are creative, mind blowing, unmercifully devilish, and delicious!" I know, in-was confused for a minute too.

LAKtVqV6KlpE1f5gsabixg.text: It is definitely not an authentic Chinese restaurant. The taste is more Ameican like.  The Mapo tofu is not special at all, but their noodle bowl is really good. One thing I like about them is when I order to go, they will separate the soup and noodle.

0FOHsc6X_saEVFJTB5qG4Q.text: DISCLAIMER:  I did not order food at Lulu's because I heard it is awful.  This is probably True because there was no one in there when I went.  I did order a Mango slushie with bubbles that was fairly unmemorable for $3.75.  Lulu's has a very Americanized interior and, you can eat-in or go to the to-go counter.  It was eighty degrees out, and I wanted a mango slush with bubbles!  I had previously seen that Lulu's sold them, so Sophia H. and I stopped in.  I was hoping this would be like Mango Mango in Chinatown in NYC with real mango, but it was not.  There were HUMONGOUS ice chunks and barely any bubbles!  There was no real mango, just flavoring.  I would have been OK with this had the slush been better, but eh.  Cash only.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Mango slush... $3.75

ZS-PWBakLe2QLbnhjRAROQ.text: We are visiting Pittsburg and came across this place for their Boba (which was fantastic). The Ramen that I had was okay. (Herb Ramen)  It smelled bad and only tasted okay. The shrimp in it was good but the broth wasn't that good. The other food that our table had looked and smelled good. I would just stay away from the ramen, but the other food should be fine and definitely try the boba.

Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu

n8kLZI3N8wA5S4yUy-8k8A.text: I ordered something called pan fried noodle. Trust me, it will be the worst noodle you will eat in your entire life.

TMb4E71SY89yTRK1UnxYgA.text: Lulu's will always have a special place in my heart.  It's where my wife and I went for our first date in college, and we've been there more times than I could possibly guess.    The portions are generous, service has always been very good, and the food comes out very fast even on the busiest of nights.  But it seems like in recent years the typical college student crowd has drifted away.  The food is as good as ever, if not better, but some recent changes to the menu have taken away my favorite dishes.  The change from thin sliced beef to ground beef in the Chow Fun Beef broke my heart.  But my wife tried substituting pork in the dish, and it was actually even better than the original beef.  Their pad thai is my go-to.  We've probably been here 100+ times over the years, and I can honestly say I've never had a bad experience.  It's a great spot for an affordable, filling meal.  If you're looking for an authentic Asian cuisine, there are certainly better options out there.  Losing some menu favorites was disappointing, and the remaining menu is starting to feel somewhat dated to early 00's Asian with a twist.  But Lulu's continues to have all of the charm and strong flavors that have made it a favorite for years.

0AZe7lA2zz4ZsF9w8c9iyA.text: I think this place deserves a lot more credit than the overall star rating right now gives it, and it boils down to expectations. I saw that this place offered affordable, quick service Asian dishes, and a wide variety of them. And guess what, that's exactly what I got! The service was fast and friendly, and the food was good quality for the price. It's about the same price as a fast food type Asian place (like Panda Express) but doesn't taste like fast food. I ordered the scallion crepe and braised wonton noodles and was pleased with the taste. It's a great place if you're craving non greasy Asian food.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Braised wonton noodles. Comes with a broth but I ate mine without it
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Scallion crepes are yummy and taste like a tortilla with green onions

LhLNuu5rx40vXUxoLTsDNw.text: Sad. This used to be one of my favorite spots for cheap eats back in my college days. A lot must have changed in the past 7 years because this is not the Lulu's I remember. I swear that their general tso's chicken used to be some of the best in the city, but on my recent visit the general tso's was terrible. Every piece of chicken was full of that super chewy inedible fat. Hardly any meat at all. Their boba tea was okay, but nothing great. I will say that the staff is extremely nice and service was prompt, so that's a plus. But I won't be returning.

ClcDCfdw6haSvQ-XXGvYJg.text: If you've come to LuLu's for fine dining and stellar customer service, you're in the wrong place.   However, that doesn't mean you can't get a tasty, plentiful meal for a reasonable price.    You order and pay for your meal at the counter, get a number and then find a seat of your choice.  The food comes out to your table very quickly.  My go to meal is the Spicy Thai Basil which is filled with chicken, pea pods, basil and peppers over a bed of noodles.   It's really filling and pretty darn cheap.     Located right near Pitt and CMU, it's a busy place when classes are in full swing, and it's affordable for college students.  This isn't authentic Asian cuisine and if you are looking for that, this probably isn't the right destination for you, but if you are in the area regularly, it's a good stop for a quick lunch.

hHx8WaMZ3ewZSSIDSGKwhA.text: Absolutely disgusting. With such a limited menu, you'd think they would perfect the dishes they had. But no. Just disgusting tasting.

F6KS0Ui0dWwmD061_yiaZg.text: Like some said, this place is not for fine dinning. It's college setting with college student pricing. Maybe if you want to get lunch with kids after going to the museum nearby.  This is the place to go.   Haven't try most of the items on the menu yet. Mainly I go for Chow fun beef or Singapore rice noodles. Both of these dishes are from Hong Kong and so am I. So there you go.

8XGu1X_1eR3bdvSAKNsyWQ.text: Excellent service and greeeeat food! A Pittsburgh must!! Quaint dining hall with ample seating.  Ambience is that of a bustling Thailand Hotspot on certain times of the day.  Food comes out hot, fresh annnnnd FAST!! On top of all this.... The ppl running this place are generous and courteous!  Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. BBQ pork, fried rice and pho soup (not pictured)

NINZ0Ci42TgIagJFTcWY-w.text: Lulu's is not very good. I would have given it a 2 but it's so cheap that its almost worth it. The primary complaint is the food is very gelatinous. The taste is bad but the texture is what is so off putting. If you are to go to LuLu's - get something that doesn't require a sauce or one of the noodle dishes that are in a broth. However, there are plenty of better places in the immediate area.

GgMXRLvXFX1OFPlFRHK5FA.text: This place will always be a solid place. I was in the Pitt community for a while, so heading over to Lulu's was as simple as walking back through Cathy to get there. Like in the name, this place is good for noodles. The ambiance is fine, and not too loud or anything.  I used to frequent here, and I would go for the Pad Thai. It is flavorful. The prices could be cheaper though.   Other than that all around good place. 3/5 stars

1KCiLUaLu5jmWxNDBwG2-Q.text: Average, really average....The server was friendly, and able to make suggestions and offer modifications based on my preferences. But when the food came out it wasn't warm enough or flavorful enough for me.   I also don't like that they serve drinks in plasticware....does all of that get recycled? I'm grateful for real silverware and plates.  They appear to keep the place clean enough... And are attentive. But overall, meh.

RH29e7dlLHFz6d8nP3ppUA.text: Used to come here a lot between masses when I was the Senior Cantor at St. Paul Cathedral back in the 90's. Szechuan Green Beans, Wonton Noodle and Ramen Soups as well as Pho, yum! Once though, between masses the sriracha sauce was clogged and when it did come out it gushed right into my eye. Oh my!  Wasn't one of my best performances following that at the 1:00pm mass!!!  Was having a little bit of a sinus problem. Ha!

P-Ha0vaAYHQHLwGySlUMCQ.text: Worst service ever experienced at a Chinese restaurant. I paid our (my friends and I) meal with credit card. After running the card, the waitress came back for me to sign the receipt. Before I signed it, she asked me how much I would pay for the tip. I was stunned because the way she said it made me feel like I was silly and I've never been to a restaurant before. She saw I didn't reply to her so she started to speak in Chinese (we were Chinese and we both knew it, I don't know why she kept speaking in her poor English but that's ok). Then she told me I had to pay at least 15%. I don't know why she assumed I didn't know it. I think her attitude was very impolite, and even rude. I will never go there again.

QIo85aycqjN_EJnez8jpfg.text: The food is just gross. I tried it twice. The first I ordered take out and ended up throwing it in the trash. The second I ate in, but actually couldn't eat much of anything. There won't be a third time.

OS3e5zG6Qk4ogpQ3-EMxaw.text: I think the trick to getting non-chunky taro bubble tea here is to request it as a smoothie--which, not surprisingly, means upping the price.    If you're in Oakland and in the mood for some greasy noodles (sometimes I actually am), Lulu's can be all right.  The menu is pretty clear on which dishes can be made vegetarian, which I appreciated.  I don't really expect authenticity with a Pan-Asian place, so I'd go with dishes that are less "traditional," like the chow fun or the pan-fried noodles.  Big portions, pretty fast.  Don't think I need to mention the service here--other people have covered that.  It'd be nice, though, if when you ordered the taro bubble tea (non-smoothie), that they'd warn you that the drink came with taro bits.  I've never had a taro bubble tea anywhere else that wasn't smooth (other than the boba).  But I guess I shouldn't expect that, given the general quality of service here.

h_Z_hBVDDScjbDwzTfTHwg.text: Cafeteria Korean, Thai, and Chinese culinary low end. The menu has many options and after trying many of them I have come to the conclusion that the food is half-assed in authenticity but more a place to grab something quick for college students who want cheap food without the fuss, and may not know of better restaurants. Slow bad service, kind of dirty, stale environment.  I'm not a big fan of Chinese food to begin with so I have gone for the noodle Thai dishes more often. I don't even know why I kept going back besides my ex really liked General Tso's chicken and would grab takeout on his way home from work.  These were all bland boring, nothing special and never ordered again. Sweet and sour chicken, shrimp-NO Spicy Basil- all spice, could taste nothing else Dr. Fu special-never get seafood here  Below were the items that were just OK. No complaints but no accolades either. Cucumber salad- not so bad Pad Thai-Frozen pad Thai is better Singapore Rice noodles- flavorless chicken, sauce do-able  Uhm so horrible, the meat was that chewy gristle kind that you spit out into the napkin. Sesame cold noodles-worms in peanut butter sauce Lard Nar Bbq pork-gummy noodles like eating mush Pho-worst ever nothing like good pho, bad broth  The bubble smoothies are really good except I can't stand the tapioca fish egg consistency. No bubbles for me, and no more Lulu's either.

dpgfjn4Vzw6lLZqoWqNadA.text: I literally couldn't eat my food here....  it was like someone poured a bottle of ketchup on some chicken and rice... very disappointing.

Yj7U2pJBia_nK6jeYcGCfQ.text: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant . Bubble is so good, try mango smoothie. It is a good summer drink. I usually get pa Thai chicken and crab Rangoon . Staffs are friendly and fast . Cool place hang out.

-xGk4QCrJt7FA40CrkhL_A.text: was on this side of town, so decided to run in  and get a quick bite. Prices weren't bad. I ordered the chow fun and singapore noodles. shared it with a friend. food was so bland, so oily, and the chow fun noodles were semi hard, and soft in certain areas. did they microwave this? really gross. The singapore noodles had 3 bean sprouts and maybe a 1X1 piece of meat.  I figure, can't go wrong with Bubble tea. NEGATIVE! there were clumps of powder at the bottom of my glass. GROSS. They stay open cause CMU students really have little choices.

Hld1LKMrJhvoDaI9k77IWw.text: I love the lunch specials, esp. the Thursday one that comes with an eggroll, ...good prices, and the soup/hot tea is great comfort food for when you're trying to keep warm and fight off a cold.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

sSrCnLbG0-WJzYnYsp2dGg.text: A solid pan-Asian noodle joint. Aside from a weird few months many years ago the food here is always top notch. Its not gourmet, but it is heads and tails above most Americanized Chinese/Asian places. Cheap too, which is nice.

uTpQRcC_LPnL_-eFnbRW1g.text: Pros: Bubble drinks are good. Wings and crab rangoon are crispy. Good service.  Cons: Noodles were overcooked and either drenched in too much sauce or too dry/bland. Definitely not authentic asian cuisine.

LxKGZKhkIkWgSOhVXePm9w.text: One of my great pet peeves about restaurant talk is the pretentious "it's not authentic" comment. I know a high school spanish teacher who is continually sniping at my enthusiasm for a few local Am-Mex dives because he's travelled to Mexico and knows what is "authentic." As far as I see it, if it is food you can taste and digest, it's "authentic." Plastic Grapes are not authentic, for example. Canned ravioli IS authentic.  Lulu's serves food of Asian origin, evolved to reflect the character of the proprietors and staff. It is from Pittsburgh, not Pyong Pinghu. And it's delicious. I couldn't give a cat's butt about faithfulness to it's heritage, not when I'm having little pleasure tremors as each bite of the szechuan bowl's peanutty cilantro goodness hits my tongue.  I've never had a bad dish here--no one in my family has. The soups are fantastic, especially the Tom Kha Kai. Even the mighty General Tso, Emperor of Inauthenticity, seems better here. My kid loves that stuff and--hells bells I'm not that proud--so do I. I always pinch a couple bites, and have noted that the chicken here is several steps above the skanky cuts most asian places use--no fat clots, no gristle and tendons, and that's saying something.  The frozen fruit drinks are fantastic. Mango are my favorites. The wife and kid #1 had pineapple and watermelon--pineapple tasted good, but the watermelon tasted just like an acutal watermelon, no "wow" explosion of taste.  Service was brisk, but not brusque.    Give it a shot. You won't be sorry.

dSVDff_k6KmrGhMpkXGsBA.text: I've loved this place since I was a student at Pitt many moons ago. The food is great and the prices are wonderful! Try the Taro Bubble Tea, Yellow Thai Curry, Pad Thai, General Tso's (it's smooth batter results in a crispy texture and sauce is perfect), and Pan Fried Noodles! YUM!

bTfmDI1GxZGmcUN9b7pixw.text: They forgot my order, I waited 25 minutes for my bubble tea. The worst attitude I have ever experienced.

4CMFrs6YQpLsqC6ajWzK-Q.text: Food is somewhere between average and good.   I don't think they will go above 3 stars in my book until they clean the various hardened food splatters off the wall where you sit and eat lunch.  I will have to try the bubble tea and perhaps food to go next time.

fottFy2sPKaaju9mf134iw.text: Food okay and staff is fairly attentive except for one short waitress who is always grumpy. Last time, she took my order wrong and didn't even apologize.

o3c1QhmPnDrY7FyAjaWaCA.text: the rice was like yesterday's left over and the chicken in the bowl was haste to chew. also boba tea is nothing like boba but just some melted ice. no recommendation on this restaurant.

gMWpkVqG5RgxQwpM2P34pw.text: After waiting 30 minutes for a lunch take out order, i asked them where my order was.  5 minutes later they informed me they didn't have the noodle i ordered (lulus pan fried veggy noodle).  So they made me pad thai, and refunded my original order in cash.

lZlZ0_kLn0ojdx38sTldBQ.text: My wife and I went to Lulu's for lunch after visiting the Carnegie Art Museum, having found Lulu's on Garmin's Mapsource for my GPS as a restaurant within easy walking distance of the museum.  After reading some Yelp reviews, and comparing Lulu's with some other restaurants, we decided it was as good as any others and seemingly better than some in the area (Ali Baba, our first choice, isn't open on Saturdays).  I got Singapore Noodles, and my wife the Beef and noodles dish.  The service was fast, the food delicious (though mine was a bit light on the curry sauce and, upon mentioning this to our delightful waitress resulted in the dish being taken back to the chef, with the result of a nice amount of additional sauce added--they keep it light for American tastes, but I like it a bit heartier, and that's what I got after mentioning it).  The veggies in the Singapore noodles were done just right--crisp and tasty, with lots of chicken and shrimp, and other requisite goodies for that dish.  My wife said she really liked the Beef noodle dish, and gave me a taste--it was indeed yummy.  Next time we're downtown near Lulu's for lunch I think I'll try that one.  The place is bright and airy, with lovely modern surroundings, great wait staff, and clearly good food, and interestingly, not at all expensive for what you receive!  Great restaurant!  ...Next time too, I think I saw on the menu one of my old favorite Korean dishes: BiBimBop.  I suspect that'll be worth a try also.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Singapore Noodles
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lulu&#39;s Noodles Interior
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef &amp; Noodles

zEs8yxTXgH0hL2GZLxeA5A.text: This place just gives off mediocrity like a bad stench.  It was bustling when I stopped by here recently for lunch - must be the decent prices, quick service, large portions, and central location.  Lulu's is not a bad place, don't get me wrong, just don't expect authenticity or anything beyond normal Americanized Asian fast food.  I had the Friday lunch special - the "chicken wing appetizer" or whatever was noooo good, and consisted of 2 wings placed awkwardly on the same platter as me overdrenched beef szechuan.  Or, what I thought was supposed to be beef szechuan.  The funny thing is, there was no spice kick to it whatsoever.  The redeeming quality was my friend's seaweed salad, which was delicious!  Covered in yummy sesame oil.  I'm sure there are other hidden gems on the menu, but I didn't find any.  Come here if you're in the mood for a huge MSG kick during your class lunch break, if you're short on time or money, or if you just want to avoid the even-worse places in the area.

JrkZEjHqVqDmgfd9ol0sXw.text: I would definitely agree with many of the other reviews-if you are looking for actual Asian food, you better look somewhere else.    If you are looking for a quick fix of salt, carbs, and oil, LuLu's is your best bet. The portions are pretty big, service is fast, and the food is relatively cheap. The lo-mein and singapore style noodles are pretty good.

eMdeZEJ9-etmU8LlwIpadQ.text: Like Little Asia on the same street, come here with no illusions. Realize that this is a lunchroom. It does an okay job on some noodle dishes, but overall meh. There is definitely better Asian food than this in Pittsburgh.

wPWxKUiSAbYZa_5eshNS9w.text: I mean, go here when school is out -- you'll get better food. Welcome to 75% of Oakland.  I'm boring and usually get Chicken Lo Mein. Other menu items are more hit and miss, so I gave up trying new things and just go with that. The chicken is always my favorite part - it's always tender and not dried out.   Sure you can find more authentic, but it's cheap, decent food. And remember, when school is out...

ne7ql0yvlMPwXITJOpk1ug.text: I'm not the type to write Yelp reviews, but my recent experience at Lulu's made me want to do a public service and warn people to not eat here. Lulu's has gone seriously downhill in the last few years.   Some lowlights of our experience:  - Had to ask for napkins twice to no avail. Finally had to get up from the table, walk to the counter, and fetch some myself. Hello, where's my waitress? - No cutlery came with our food, so had to ask for some. Chopsticks arrived 5 minutes after noodles did. - Beef pho was absolutely inedible - lukewarm, flavorless, disgusting. I had to send it back to the kitchen. If you've ever had real pho, don't get it at Lulu's. Best case scenario you'll be sorely disappointed, more realistic is that you'll want to gag and be sick at the table. - "Pan-fried noodles" are actually just an uncooked circular ramen brick covered in warm chicken and bok choy. I know Lulu's is catered towards the budget-conscious college crowd, but I could've saved more money and time just by buying a $0.25 packet of Maruchan from CVS and eating it straight from the bag.  The only tasty thing at Lulu's is the Sriracha sauce.

Ds9VZSw8lE06jrWbKb7rUQ.text: A good quick lunch place. Decient sized portions with good food! Cool atmosphere stepping it up from your typical Pho joint.  Minimum $10 on credit cards with no atm around so be prepared to bring cash if you just have a single order.

Cyk-YlaTJRcV5uBtKoGrlA.text: Love Lulus! Who cares if it is authentic or not! I wonder what authentic "Asian" food is really?  Lulus is fast Asian food... and furious...and cheap! It was a regular go-to lunch joint while I was in school in Oakland. The school days are behind me, but I still look for opportunities to go get a bite there when I can. I like their noodles, the rices, but the small plates are my fave. The pad thai is pretty decent (again, I don't know what authentic is, if it tastes good, I will eat it). The bubble tea, however, is not the best. The tapioca pearls are a little too hard for my liking. The actual tea part is delish!

BCktVmBUKAtch39Bn6W0wg.text: I love Lulu's - when I attended Pitt, my friends and I would practically eat here every week. While these dishes may not be the most authentic versions you'll ever eat, some of their noodle ones are very tasty - and plentiful! I can typically get two meals and a small snack out of a single order.  I recommend the Pad Thai and Singapore Rice Noodle, but my all time favorite is the Pan Fried Noodle with Chicken. Yum!

61obLw_njVBLo5cEqPqFVw.text: I think the trick to having a good experience at Lulu's is to know what you're getting into before you walk in: average Asian cuisine, average service, cheap prices. By using these metrics, I usually have had a good experience here (I've been maybe 3 or 4 times). Typically, I never am hungry enough to get a "Big Eat" from the menu, I just stick with one of the "Small" vegetarian meals and it suits me well. The last few times I've gotten the steamed vegetables with tufu, and a $4.25 a bowl you can't have many complaints. It's been a nice place to walk over to from work, and it's great that it's open until almost 10pm to serve the college crowds from Pitt and CMU. And definitely try one of the bubble smoothies at some point- they were all the rage when they came out a few years ago and are actually quite tasty (if overpriced).

LPBy-M-ZJk611QCmZOhtMw.text: Definitely good food. My wife and I both enjoyed our meals. She had the shrimp wonton soup and u had the Singapore noodles plate. Service was adequate. My biggest complaint was the noise. The music was really loud in the bathroom and there was nothing to dampen the sound so the kid flying the airplane on the other side of the room seemed to echo next to us. But remember, the food tasted good and regardless of the few things, we will be back for different meals.

2sMMj16R0mDYXZWn917KbA.text: Lulu's noodles is in an extremely convenient location for students coming from CMU, so it should be no surprise that most weekdays around lunch time the place is packed.  The few times I have been there I have found the food to be okay, nothing to write home about. The Pho was utterly terrible, and the various noodle dishes only passable. The biggest problem, though, has been with the service. You place your order at the counter, and they are supposed to bring it to you. Several times I've found myself forgotten and having to go back to ask where my food is.  All in all, it will do in a pinch if you're a CMU student, otherwise steer clear.

sScg2ruL9SlCymAGbxiyfw.text: My girlfriend was eager to go back to Lulu's as she was a regular during her days attending Art Institute of Pittsburgh. So it looked like a great place for an evening snack (not really a late night place).   First the bad. I ordered the Korean bibimbap bowl with duck. The bowl was topped with kimchi and duck. The duck was greasy but tasty and the kimchi was a little dry. Beneath this thin layer of toppings was an iceberg size portion of rice. Too much rice. Now, I like rice, but I like rice with something to go with it. It's like eating plain bread, doesn't make sense, you need your pb & j to top your bread. Now the bowl was only $7, which explains all the rice, but still, give me something, anything, to sauce my rice.  Now the good. I had a mango smoothy and some scallion pancakes. The mango smoothy was made from fresh mangos and definitely hit the spot. I'd get a big gulp of that next time. The scallion pancakes were the thinnest pancakes I've had. I've had medium thickness (my moms pancakes), thick pancakes (little dragons in Columbus, OH) and now thin. I really enjoyed the thin, easier to munch on and you taste the salt and oniony-ness more. The mango smoothie and scallion pancakes each earned the 2 stars for Lulu's.   Maybe next time I'll just get mango smoothies and onion pancakes.

v6e3lm4bZdmfqbqXaFB6YQ.text: I was here once before, and it wasn't impressive enough for me to return until my daughter, who loves Asian food, and I were in Oakland and hungry for dinner.  She really wanted bubble tea, and I knew Lulu's had it and was close.  We each ordered bubble milk tea.  My daughter had the red bean, and I had the almond.  She ended up liking mine better, since the red bean had a very floral taste to it which she was not used to.  I traded with her, even though the almond was definitely better.  For food, I had the Pad Thai, and she had Sesame Cold Noodles.  My dish was not aesthetically appealing, but it tasted OK.  It was not spicy at all, so I added quite a bit of Sriracha.    Once again, my daughter wasn't very pleased with her selection, even though she said it was good.  She ended up eating half my plate instead, which  was fine by me, since the serving was large.  I did try her noodles, and they seemed OK.  The service was very good for us.  The server was concerned when my daughter didn't eat her food and offered to take it back, but we weren't that concerned about it.  I wouldn't recommend making a special trip to go to Lulu's, but if you're in the area and don't want to spend a lot of money, it will pass.  I will be opting for Crepes Parisienne down the street.

JJIdvtDIyc31YQDvvUfAfQ.text: The rice is dry; the general flavor is lacking in pad thai, hong kong noodles, gyoza and jasmine tea.  Cleanliness of bathrooms is on par with moderately clean gas station.

rrmkIGjg1Bx3M9gHV3ysUQ.text: I was looking for some good hot and sour soup (I think you can totally judge a restaurant by its ability to make Hot and Sour soup) and we ended up at this lovely little place. I can see it being a pain during peak hours/times due to parking and limited seating, but I kind of think its worth the wait.  One - they put Sriracha sauce on every table. Two - the Hot & Sour soup is nom Three - they had crispy noodle dishes!!!  I had the LuLu Pan Fried Noodles with pork. While I didn't really care for their pork, the pan fried noodles were deelish. I had these once in another Chinese restaurant in Durham, but I could never remember the name of the dish or how to describe it.   I don't think LuLu's stands out as a particularly awesome Chinese restaurant, but it certainly wasn't bad. If you're looking for something that isn't too authentic, I'd totally recommend this place.

GiPH5uadPpIX43Ll-9gr4w.text: Big menu.  Quick take out service.  Really flavorless food.  So disappointing.  It is hard to make take out noodles tasteless.  Maybe it is because we ordered it with no MSG?  I don't know, but I won't be coming back here again.

s2BIv_oS-jt9qAYH-UzqjA.text: I was hungry 2 hours later because I threw it all away. What a soggy, processed, heap of goo this was. I had the teriyaki chicken, the rest of my family had the general tso's chicken. The Tso's was thickly breaded and the chicken in mine was as if it was cut off of a lump of chicken loaf. Remember the "Turkey dinner" you used to get in your high school cafeteria? Well, there you go. Utterly bland and ultimately inedible.

hZid49xJDRBJcniTcQVpdw.text: Still love Lulu's. So great for vegetarians. And you can get a delicious customized fresh fruit smoothie for $3.50.

xpTdkI5QQfgMVanDU1IfiA.text: We stopped by LuLu's since it was close to the CMU campus and we were hungry. There is ample seating which was nice so we sat immediately.   I was very excited to see the selection on their menu and decided to order one of my favorites - singapore noodles. While the noodles were at least (light) yellow, the flavoring of the spices was barely there, which was unfortunate. *insert sad face* In addition to that we shared a mango bubble tea but it tasted like the maker elbowed in a can of heavy syrup.   On the flip side my boyfriend enjoyed his wonton soup and my chow foon the second time around was just okay but better than the singapore noodles.   The food is cheap but I wouldn't take the initiative of coming here. It makes sense that they are near universities and cater to college students though. Their food is mediocre at best but service has been okay.

zwYsVZaN2oKriDEgWklp8Q.text: Since we have been attending a church in the Oakland neighborhood of Pittsburgh, our family has really been enjoying exploring the nearby restaurants after worship.  This was my third visit to Lulu's.  My first visit, I went with the Pad Thai.  Same with the second visit.  Both times, the Pad Thai hit the spot and the price was definitely right.    This last visit was on a Sunday afternoon and every single table was taken.  Even with the packed restaurant, our order was taken quickly and the food arrived not too long after.  The only service hiccup was in trying to get our check and some to go boxes for our leftovers.  For our family of 4, we ended up with: - Fried Wontons (kinda different, kinda good with the red bean filling) - Gyoza (never got one - the kids gobbled them up quickly) - Yeung Chow Fried Rice (the entree I ordered - very tasty, not too greasy, a little heavy on the onions) - Lard Nar BBQ Pork (my wife ordered this - I scored a bite and it was very good!)  I don't claim to be an expert on Asian cuisine (though I happen to be Asian myself).  Lulu's has a pretty expansive menu that covers quite a few different countries.  Considering the scope and the low prices on the menu, I don't expect perfection.  This is cheap eats place that does what it does well.    I read a few of the other reviews of Lulu's and pleased that my experience has been completely different.  We'll be back...

0mxAR3lpLdWu1E_TLKqJww.text: I love Thai and I love noodles so this was going to be a match. Fail.   This review is for takeout only.  Dishes were water slogged and had a sad bit of peanuts thrown in to keep it real. Tore our stomachs up and threw away remaining food. Guess the stomach of a college student is more forgiving than us old farts.

yi5REU5rOei4f4I6OINt_g.text: I used to come here all the time but over the past 10 years the food quality has degraded to practically inedible. Mushy, overcooked veggies, low quality meats, and crappy generic "asian" style sauces. So sad, as this used to be a tasty place for reasonably priced Chinese.

HPJExIDsAFiw8hV58K2LiA.text: First note:  If the reviewer's hometown ends in ", CA", don't trust the review.  Stuffy declarations about the authenticity of the food are waaaaay out of context in this scenario.  And listen, stuck-up Californians: I used to live in WUHAN, CHINA and I like it.  So shut up.  It's not authentic, and that's the point.  Lulu's is cheap.  Let us not forget this.  Your table might be a little sticky, the place may be a little loud, and the decor may be a little goofy, but if you are here and you know what you're getting into, you know there will be a delicious abundance of carbohydrates headed your way for very little money.    I've read a lot of accusations that the staff there is rude.  I haven't seen this at all, having now been there a number of times.  Singapore Rice Noodles is what you get when you go to Lulu's... if you're me.  There are probably other things that are really tasty, too, but the Singapore Noodles are consistently recommended by everyone I talk to about this place.  I've never had the bubbletea.  I'm not really a sweet-drinks kind of fellah.  I'm sure I'll try it someday, though.  Go here for a quick, cheap bite.  Don't listen to the naysayers.

CeA9Rmu2zV19LmiswAHAmQ.text: They had so many health code violations so they were shut down for some time. I can't comment on how their food is...post health code violations.   I wasn't a huge fan of the food before the violations -it just seemed like generic food that I could get anywhere. It's ok for a casual dinner out but there are better places in Pittsburgh for that.   The saving grace is that they do have huge portions so you almost always have leftovers.

vugSJcsVNMKF8nahxrVSEA.text: The food's alright, the bubble tea is good.   The credit card limit used to be $10, but they've recently upped it to $15. If you're planning to stop in for something small, make sure you have cash on hand.

JWKVn2fWwWDxkfsNJo8jjw.text: My boyfriend wanted to grab some Asian food close to home, and this fit the bill.  The service overall was good in that the waitress who I presume to be the owner of the place was very attentive and polite.   There weren't many customers when we went, so the food fortunately came out quickly. I ordered the wonton noodle soup which was pretty good on the cold stormy day that we went. Pretty standard with the shrimp wontons and simple soup. My boyfriend ordered the chicken chow fun which was good too.  The reason for the deducted stars? I don't know if I'm being completely fair BUT or server asked us if we wanted water or hot tea. So we assumed the tea would be free. It was not. Each hot tea was $3.25. I don't want to be unfair, but I have a suspicion she knew that we were clueless to this fact. I wish we were better informed. Also, the food was okay but not worth the cost in my opinion.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

drCiKRYHwjdRocmSyL3vbg.text: Oh, Lulu. I still like you, I guess, but with your menu redesign, you took off all of the things I usually ordered. Singapore rice noodles and chow fun beef are gone. Ugh.  This place isn't what it used to be, and it shows. I haven't seen this place busy in a long time.  While our waiter was really attentive and had great suggestions during our visit today, they were out of bubbles for bubble tea and there was no toilet paper in the bathroom. When I went to ask another host about restocking the TP in the women's room, she tried to reach for the empty napkin holder to tell me to use those because they were out. Yikes. That's not something you want to tell a patron at a restaurant.  Here's the one entree I can still get behind: Order the chow fun with pork. It's very good.

3nxBREhfysbO5WEG0qxudA.text: We had a hankerin' for ramen and found most places nearby are closed on Sundays.  I bookmarked Lu Lu's a while ago but the 2.5 average star rating kept me away.  Due to it being the only place open, and today being a sunny and warm day, we decided to put caution to the wind and go for it.    Glad we did!  The ramen was very good.  We both got "Soul Ramen" and selected the pork dumpling to go with it.  It also had an intact hardboiled egg.  We had a bit of fun lifting it out of the bowl with chopsticks.  Somehow I had no trouble while my wife, who grew up using chopsticks, dropped it back in the bowl causing quite a splatter all over us and the table.  We laughed over that for a bit!!  It'll be our lasting memory of this place.  My only complaint is with the tea.  I simply ordered hot tea and when the bill arrived I was surprised to see I was charged for bubble tea.  Apparently that's the only tea they have and I simply didn't ask for any of the boba stuff.  Next time I'll just ask for water.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soul Ramen with pork dumplings and a hard boiled egg.
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

iCNImMlkEt66IHWgRWPERA.text: Not a fan. The food is cheap which is nice, but it's not very good. I got one of the soups (the one with pork broth) and it was just unpleasant. It was just a lot of water with a dim pork flavor which was kinda gross. The veggies in it were cooked well and the staff was friendly enough but honestly that's about it. If you're going to get some noodles in the city there are so many better places for about the same price.

StG6rYthFEF0CsCvXSN7FA.text: Another Pittsburgh staple that seems to be taken for granted. There was a time when I'd eat here once a week. However it's been a couple of years and probably why I've never reviewed. If you come in during weekday lunch hours orders are placed, paid for and picked up at counter.  Evening meals are traditional sit-down with a server. I've been here when it's super packed and when it's not busy at all and the food is always consistent. Sauces, meats, veggies burst with flavor. A variety of noodles always cooked to perfection with tastes you'd expect from a noodle joint.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

UaUoz1nZMKcueYr8zIK_IQ.text: Lulu's Noodles has turned cafeteria style in the worse way. Quality of food is the same but the service is below average.  I had walk in looking confused and the workers there just let me stand there to figure it out on my own.  Definitely not going back.

7XkSHeLCnV0Nnj8Bm4fDkg.text: It is okay.  3 star is just correct.  One of best menu you should order is  ****Wonton noodle soup****  Shrump and pork in wonton dumpling only 4 star menu in this restaurant.  ORDER WONTON NOODLE SOUP

cms7HSe_qF3CwcMwSzxSKA.text: Lulu's used to be my favorite place not only in Oakland, but pretty much anywhere near Pittsburgh. Lately though, they did something to the menu! They got rid of my favorite dishes and changed the way they prepare a lot of their old stuff. If I go now, I stick to crab Rangoon and Hawaiian fried rice. Other than that, I'll pass. Sorry Lulu's!

JA4Ixhz2XQplp08zaaGWzQ.text: Dear Lulu, what happened to you?  We were a thing for 20 years, us two.  Three if including Dr. Foo  But the last few visits left me bereft. What say you?  No more Singapore rice noodle, but a "Szechuan" bowl of goo?  Have you seen what's going on around you?  Pittsburgh's food scene is lit. It's passed you by, what'll you do?  Have you become so addicted to college "tastes" as to say "ah, screw?"  You're phoning it in, and this 20-yr customer cries boo-hoo through his toodaloo, because I must bid you adieu.

pmTQtGSUJ02dcKsXpIDYpw.text: I ordered general tso chicken and ate there but ending up packing my chicken to go. I ran out of rice so I paid an extra $1 and they gave me a packed container of rice. The chicken was really delicious so imagine my horror when on my fourth chopstick scoop of rice...I find a hair. I really don't want to know where it came from and I drop my phone a lot so my camera doesn't have the best quality but just watch what you put in your mouth wherever you go. I think I'm too disgusted to go back but if anyone is interested, they also have really good pad Thai and wonton noodle soup.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

27IKDWPbsC6cS4TFCBEHJA.text: I have only been once the spring rolls were pretty good but the noodles were just okay

ZezYtmDCXGZ0sXB79fWiAA.text: Lulu's takes me back to my college years! Prices are very good for a sit-down restaurant. Every entree is under $10. I've been here multiple times over the years, and unfortunately, their vegetarian dishes have always been pretty bland. All my meat-eating friends have no complaints so that makes me think that they just can't serve a good veggie dish. I've tried everything from their fried rice to the pad thai but I'm usually unsatisfied. Very average quality food. I'm usually adding half the salt shaker to my meal to taste something.   This time around, I ordered the Tofu Teriyaki Bowl which is probably one of the better items on their menu that I've had. Portion size was very generous and the special soy sauce was delicious. The vegetables themselves were tasteless (and not fresh) so I had to drown them in the soy sauce to be tolerable. We also had their bubble tea which is usually very good but this time, it was so watery and bland. My experiences here have been very hit or miss; however, service is always great - friendly waiters/waitresses that are attentive and prompt when you have a request.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hong Kong Bowl
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pan Fried Noodles

4nBdyq9xHifehY1lEUIFAA.text: Not sure what has happened it's been awhile since I've eaten here and will probably be the last time. The wonton soup was huge disappointment. It smelled off and tasted even worse. The rest of our take out order included shrimp fried rice, chicken pad Thai, egg rolls, and shrimp noodle dish all of which were overall blah. They lacked flavor and the quality of ingredients was poor. I don't know if the ownership has changed or they are trying to save money but it shows in the food.

NahW7tlj7AIZV45sC7WUTQ.text: This was one of my go-to places when I was in college.  Cheap, fast and good.  It seems as though it has gone down hill a bit over the past few years.  We arrived an hour and a half before closing, but still felt rushed by our server.  We ordered a side of fried rice for the kids that was initially forgotten, but brought to the table along with the bill (after we were pretty much finished eating).  My usual Sauteed Chicken Noodle bowl was lukewarm and the noodles were one large blob at the bottom of the bowl.  If this were my only experience, I probably wouldn't return.  C'mon Lulu' s - I know you are better than that!

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sauteed Chicken Noodle Bowl.

3gofxZcvZ7GPHy4ezcgEnA.text: The new menu doesn't have scallion crepes!!!!!!  Please bring them back.  Also sauteed veggies with tofu.  Customer since 1994.

2GetI28vvkAWpLtnk9Yndg.text: I have spent many weekend lunches in this place, and I admit I used to love it!  Now, I'm less than enthused to go here, but it's not that I never crave it. However, my most recent trip to visit family in Pittsburgh brought me back here and, like the other reviewers have said, it isn't what it used to be. The service isn't great, the food tastes less fresh than it used to, and I haven't even tried the bubble tea in so long, so I can't really review it, but when I used to get it, it was sub par compared to other local spots.  I always get Dr. Fu Noodles, though, and typically can't go wrong. It's a pretty plain tasting dish, but I like it with some soy sauce. Something about the pile of tiny noodles is addicting.   Overall, though, definitely not my favorite spot to go to anymore in Oakland, like it used to be. I would love to see them up their game again!

_qPKKqsJ601x7pGEPkA5LQ.text: We came years ago and they had a full menu and the place was packed. Now it's a scaled back menu and it was nearly empty when we walked in.   But the flavors were still there. My pad Thai was delicious. My wife loved the Lo Mein and both were served fast and hot.

PsBWry9YtTjvTLoHHMnT0w.text: I've heard amazing things about LuLu's food but today the staff knocked it out of the park! Our waiter was a sweet young man that was completely attentive to us. He was genuinly concerned that we were pleased with our experience. Everyone we came into contact with was so kind.  The food was exceptional and fresh!  The sweet and sour chicken and Lo Mein were exceptional. We will definitely come back!

Q4NI5tTkgVkaRyRk-93OJQ.text: Meh.  Their tapioca is okay. Their general tso's chicken is okay. Their pho is terrible.  They don't even have hoisin sauce, sprouts, mint, limes, or anything else.  They also used the wrong noodles in the tasteless broth.  Sighs!  Edit: Tried Lulu's again.  I've decided that I'm not coming back anymore, and I'll never understand why it's so packed all the time.  I got the Pad Thai and the Thai Curry.  The Thai Curry was okay, but the Pad Thai was the grossest thing I have ever seen.  It looked like someone had vomited it out, plated it, and then served.  The noodles were over cooked and floated in a bath of sweet syrupy soup.  Yeah.  Gross.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai

Bb0T0CcXVbrwz6xOcBElxQ.text: My pad thai was very sweet and had no discernible spice at all. The chicken seemed to be of low quality. I also ordered a side of fried rice which was bland and unappealing. Finally, the mango smoothie (which has been good in the past) tasted like ice cream this time.  I have never enjoyed the food on previous visits, but everyone raves about Lulu's, so I keep trying to give it a chance. I am consistently let down, so I don't think I'll be visiting Lulu's ever again.

cP6fm_w-1pIznkn9B-9reA.text: I would like to recommend lulu's fresh fruits bubble tea to everybody!!! Mango is my favorite flavor!! Beef chow fun was so delicious, I like how they put the fresh beans sprouts on top it!! Enjoy see the waitress with a warm welcome & nice service! Looking forward to go back soon!!

Z_VhNnoGql7AGP0v1p6Pzw.text: Have you heard of farm to table? Well this place should be called trash to table.  Ordered the Sizchuan noodle bowl. It was day old chicken in a thick sauce that was the consistency of super glue with mushy peanuts sprinkled on top. The noodles were just one hard solid glob you could pick up all at once - how old are they to be that congealed!    It was the most disgusting thing I've ever seen.

Fk1NSZCpcnvt4LfHIvCWRw.text: Well on the bright side this place is fairly cheap, and the portions are ginormous.  I live right next door since I go to CMU, and it's great to have something cheap close by.    On the other hand, the food is just...ok.  I guess I came in with high standards having moved from the Bay Area which is almost like little Asia.  I had the Thai Curry Chicken, which didn't have the depth of flavor most thai curries do, but it was passable.  The other people I went with had Lo Mein, which I didn't like at all, and Fried Tofu, which was fine.    Their service was great for me.  The woman who was serving us was nice, and she even split the check by person for us which many places don't do.  On the whole, I like their milk teas, so I'll be back for those, and of course the cheap food.

4vNPAOjBDsGFP-Qog3kdsQ.text: Use to love this place but after today it will be a while before I think about returning. Giant dead cockroach in women's bathroom, smell in bathroom was horrendous, walls are dirty. A restaurants cleanliness is a reflection of their kitchen. And I no longer have confidence in the food I eat from this kitchen.

KhZhWwFuPSUd8PG2eZ1TxQ.text: Like other reviewers, I'm unimpressed by Lulu's Noodles.  I've been there once, and that was enough for me.  I ordered a noodle dish of some kind, and it was bland and salty, and the ingredients were sub-par.  It's a far cry for authentic Asian food, and, having traveled several times to East Asia, I know what that is.  I also ordered the bubble tea, which was decent--however, there's now another place half a block down where you can get that for take-out or eat-in.  Based on the quality of the food, I'm surprised that this place is always packed.  Then again, I suppose it appeals mainly to the college student crowd, many of whom care about inexpensiveness over food quality.  If you're on S. Craig and looking for somewhere to eat, give this place a pass.  There are several better options (see my Craig St. restaurant list).

Y8nPTPfxX7pQHM3iiic_-Q.text: Lulu's has long become a staple to the neighboring college community in Oakland due to it's prime location on Craig St. and the price.   However, the food is terrible. I've been to Lulu's on multiple occasions during my freshman days of college, simply because I was unfamiliar to the city and craved some Chinese food (or in this case anything "asian"). As I got more familiar to Pittsburgh and found better options, I stopped dining at Lulu's completely.  Until tonight after a moment of bad judgment, my boyfriend and I just wanted some normal fried rice, and would settle for mediocre Americanized "asian" food.   I must say though, that their service is impeccably speedy. Too speedy. Within seconds of being seated and not even have had the chance to open our menus, our waitress asked us to order.  We ordered Scallion Pancakes, Java Fried Rice and Chicken Pad Thai, thinking that they can't possibly mess these very simple dishes up. How wrong we were. The fried rice was tasteless, (I'm usually complaining about food being too salty), and the pad thai was colorless, and swimming in liquid-y sauce (also smelled really bad). The Scallion Pancakes were literally store-bought tortillas with pureed scallions, so strange.   I think what baffled me the most was that our waitress only finally reappeared to chuck our bill on the table, AS WE WERE STILL EATING. Nobody motioned for the bill, we still had food in our mouths and on the plates. Definitely made us feel very very rushed. Rude.  At least their beverages are okay.. most of their flavors are pretty artificial/powdery tasting, but whatever. Could use more bubbles though.   If you have any respect for Chinese, Japanese, Thai, Korean, etc food, SKIP Lulu's. Please.

mKgqjVBcEJD3JwEx1k27jQ.text: Tasty Chinese food!..Pretty good service with nice music...

e6kDmrRYGQciRf7i5Sn0Kw.text: I have been going to LuLu's now for over 20 years!  Some of the best Asian food in Oakland!  The Japanese Eggplant is a favorite.   And the staff are always polite and helpful!  Yes, they are busy, so they have to be fast in serving you (with a smile)! As for the person complaining about the decor (noodle pictures)...do you really think they used the noodles from the kitchen?!?!  And took the pictures in the restaurant?!?!?!   Guess again...the pictures were taken in a studio and the noodles thrown away.   I would highly recommend Lulu's!

OqnRvOC4lAcG9XxKKBzf1w.text: Ok a lot of hype about this place but really disappointed in the overall flavor of the food.  I expected spicy Thai curry but no real flavor, just bland. Wife had pad Thai noodles, again not much in spice or flavor. The chicken was tasteless on both meals. Only thing going was cheap and fast, I guess you pay for what you get.

nm3Ix-jwoAX-EFqtduN0KA.text: To the reviewer who complained they were never served at lunch: This must have been due to a major miscommunication / misunderstanding. Lunch does not include table service. You place your order at the cashier, get a number, then they bring the food out when it is ready. I'm surprised you were 'seated by a host', and I'm surprised someone after you was 'served immediately'. This almost sounds like you are reviewing a different restaurant! Or at the least, mistook someone's cafeteria tray with beverages and fortune cookies (served immediately by the cashier) for having been served. Any way, better luck next time.  It is problematic that newcomers are not informed of the lunch policy. There seems to be no one working as 'host' during lunch. It is also problematic that the menu is disorganized; grouped by size "small eats" "big eats" "noodle bowls" "rice dishes". Soups are all over the place, depending on whether you order a meal sized or appetizer sized soup. This would be ok during dinner when there is table service, but instead you have to rapidly scan the menu while waiting in line at the cashier. On the bright side: there seems to be no obligation to tip during lunch!

LMYhLdytNFHftltR7NjTow.text: I personally love the bubble tea that Lulu makes so I'm a frequent customer. But today's trip to Lulu's was disastrous.  So I came to get 2 mango smoothie bubble tea today. It was ridiculous that I ended up waiting 40 minutes just for 2 bubble for to go. And when I received my order, it was 2 strawberry--not 2 mango.  I proceeded to tell the lady that she had my order wrong, but was told that she heard me say strawberry. Aside from the fact that mango and strawberry sounds nothing alike, she rudely insisted that I told her strawberry. I also did not appreciate the dirty attitude I was getting from her when I was trying to talk to her politely...  So after a while, it seems that my order was going to be fixed. But after waiting some more, I only received 1 mango and was given 1 strawberry despite telling her I ordered 2 mango, not 1 mango and 1 strawberry. This time, she was obviously being a b*tch asking, "so are you going to take it the drinks or not?"  Based on my past experience with other people there, I might come back. But if I do, I absolutely refuse to have her take my order  again.

JlAq4_uMDit7H3-7es8zag.text: This place is SUPER delicious. I just love the Singapore Rice Noodles. Highly recommended. The only downside is that it can get a little busy during dinner time and parking is hard to come by. It's worth the wait though!

3hhKjae661swO5SB0fLC5w.text: I love this place! Fast  cheap and good food! Also great location. It does suck that you have to spend a min 8 bucks to use your card since I never carry cash.

8diRVWx9Ptmw2Sqq9zVlJQ.text: LuLu's is ok when I'm feeling hungry and don't have much time. I'm glad that they finally changed their bubble tea menu that now allows you to choose options such as the kind of tea, different boba and juices that are available. You can even choose how much or little sweetener that you want in your tea. The food is sub-par. I have found that Dr. Fu's noodles are my go to dish even though the past two times I've ordered there were only five small pieces of chicken throughout the entire dish. So, go and try it but proceed with caution knowing that there are far better options out there for you.

eb0k0rGIt612loT1kj_hFg.text: HORRIBLE!  They need to train the staff in the BASICS!  My wife and I arrived at 5:45 on a Friday night; we had tickets to see John Waters at the Carnegie hall across the street at 8:00.  Simple? NO!  We placed our orders; two noodle bowls and Pot Stickers.  Over a half hour later we asked the server where our food was, we noticed our order was still on her pad!  She lied and said "soon".  Twenty minutes later our Pot Stickers were placed on someone else's table.  We had to argue with the runner to get them on our table.  (BTW, they were TERRIBLE).  Still no food by 7:30.  We had to leave or miss the event.    So I go to the cashier; "I will pay for the Pot Sticker but we must leave".  I WAS HANDED A CHECK FOR THE ENTIRE MEAL!  I ask for the Manager.  I was ignored.  I start yelling.  I'm still ignored for ten minutes.  So we left. The John Waters event was ruined because we were so hungry.  ONE HOUR AND FORTY-FIVE MINUTES!!  The entire staff at Lulu's should be ASHAMED! I am owed an apology.

mtkcw_8Ur2V6ksFHT1nnJQ.text: I wish it was a little quicker and cleaner overall. Our table was sticky and gross which made me think that the kitchen was probably not clean either. I always get what I believe are called crazy noodles and it tastes pretty good. Maybe if the service was much faster and the place was cleaner I'd go again.

XQnitjLM-CYmZqL0Uwpb0Q.text: It is True that this place is cheap and conveniently close to CMU campus, but unfortunately, their food is consistently mediocre or worse.  It is obvious that they do not use good ingredients in their cooking, and dishes are often either bland or too salty or just plain gross.

J2t5eGfzDtyVm9JcfL_Nxg.text: When I went here in 2009, the place was great. When I went here last week, it was terrible. You walk in and it's confusing- no one greets you, no one explains seating, no one gets menus, no one takes your order, the tables are dirty- it was really gross. We sat down and waited fifteen minutes before a roach scurried across by the pay station in the center and we left to get our meal at another restaurant on Craig. I don't know what these people are thinking running a restaurant like that- I really hope it was just an off day, but the roach was not promising. This is not the Lulu's I remember.

N0jnmFVgHq8E_D7-O0TgBA.text: One of my favorite places for Asian food especially on a rainy day! My favorite meal here is the Lulus japanesepan fried noodles! They're crispy, but as the sauce soaks in the noodles become soft. It can be pretty bland sometimes so I ask for spicy. However, they never seem to remember that.   They have really good bubble tea too! Lots of selection.   The kimchi rice is okay sometimes a bit too sour.   Egg rolls are average too.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

eadLEwk8vFWpegggWw6SrQ.text: This was my first time back at Lulus in over a few years. My sister, her two young children and I decided to grab lunch here on a weekday.  During lunch service you order at the counter and then you seat yourself. Luckily we were able to order before a big rush came in.  The decor has not changed much since I use to go here as a kid so it kinda has dingy/old vibe to it. However, I still love the noodle pictures that line the walls.  I ordered the pork lo mein and it was pretty good and priced about what is average for an inexpensive Asian restaurant. I remember that several years ago they had lunch specials that were a great deal. However, it seems like they do not have lunch specials anymore which was disappointing.  If you're looking for something sweet definitely try their smoothie. It was delicious!  Overall, an affordable pleasant spot to have lunch in Oakland.

_LDC5vDuAtQPn3ZUfEVfQA.text: The food is decent, but I wouldn't go as far as to say it was great. It was flavorful and came out in a good amount of time. This is a good choice for inexpensive Asian cuisine that is decently good. It has not been busy at any time I've come and you are seated quite promptly. The place itself is big, has seating for big groups, and very casual.  The waitress the first time I went was very sweet, joked with us, and was very attentive.  The second time, a young man was our waiter. He was much more impatient and at one point rolled his eyes at our debate of what to get. For what it claims to be, it deserve 3.5 stars to 4 stars.

v1M0Z80iGjQfaWN64sMpJw.text: We stopped at Lulu's for dinner one night. It was around 8 and they close at 9:30 so we were hoping we weren't too late. We came in and were greeted right away. There were only a few people in the restaurant so we were able to be seated right away. We ordered the crab Rangoon for an appetizer and I ordered a bubble tea to sip on. My fiance also ordered the wonton soup. All 3 came out very fast! The crab Rangoon was so good! One of the best I've eaten ever. The sauce they give you is duck sauce with some hot mustard in it.. and it just works! My bubble tea was so good too! For my entree, I ordered a dish that is basically chicken and green beans in a brown sauce. That was so good too! We've gone back a couple of more times since then and I order the same thing every time! Lulu's is an Oakland staple and I can definitely see why!

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Crab Rangoon (5)
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sauteed String Beans and noodle soup
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wonton Soup

8wzH6_PzlaWILXtGU9NXqw.text: I always have a great time here. The ordering style has changed a bit but the bottom line is I always get delicious ramen, and a big portion of it!!!  And the price is really good for a college student!

muGE_cw6ktomg-8GsB9wiw.text: I was stuck between giving this 3 or 4 stars but I've come here too many times to give it a 3.   * Food: I used to come here all the time so I've tried a lot of their dishes. My favorite dishes are the Hong Kong Chow Fun, Dr. Fu's Noodles and Szechuan Twice-Cooked Pork. I am not a huge fan of their rice plates because there's nothing really special to it. I would prefer to go to other local asian takeout places. Some people I know aren't huge fans of this place but for some reason, I always find myself coming back. Sure it's nothing too special but I feel like I always get a good hearty meal when I come here. I would definitely suggest people to come here at least once!       * Cost vs. Worth: Their dishes are around $8-$10 which is a good price for the amount you get.    Will I come here again? - Definitely!

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hong Kong Chow Fun with Chicken
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai with Chicken

OOvAIz6QOCK3I0AMAWbQjA.text: My favorite place in Pittsburgh! The servers are great, the food is delicious, nice and well kept place, and great prices. Overall, just amazing. Definitely recommend the Hawaii's fried rice and the sweet and sour chicken!

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sweet &amp; Sour Chicken
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hawaii&#39;s Fried Rice

JqDyPyVdTBjZkieeAilWrw.text: Was craving Asian food while in Pittsburgh and this place hit the spot. Milk tea was overly sweet and the boba was kind of hard, but the wonton noodle soup was delicious.

mTKUIkWuWu8QQ2l9UsXI_w.text: I really didn't enjoy my experience in Lulu's noodles. It looks rather cafeteria like, but when I decided to ask the person behind the stand about the details of the menu, our waiter came out and seemed to be upset about it and kept the same attitude. The food didn't improve the situation. I ordered basil noodles but received pretty much a noodle soup - so much sauce it had. Out of the Chinese places I've been to, this one is on the lower end for me, unfortunately.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Thin white noodles with veggies

Mp74LFA9fAHBoa7LDzqg0A.text: Talk about a blast from the past for me on my recent trip to Lulu's.  That can be taken two ways by the way, and I will explain.  Upon arriving in Pittsburgh after college, Lulu's use to be a spot that I always would hit up.  Living in Squirrel Hill made it convenient for my visits.  It was the place to be, when someone said Chinese food in the city, you automatically thought of this place.  Then on the other hand, this place feels trapped in the past.  Walking in here after years of dining elsewhere, nothing has changed.  Evident of that is the layer of dust on some items.  All I am saying, don't look up.  The dining area is basically the same as well.  What has changed is the way they do business.  Or maybe it was because I was here for a late lunch.  I'm not sure.  But before you were shown to a seat, now I had to do most of the work myself.  Confused me at first.  No one at the door or a sign to tell you what to do, so I just stood there for a few minutes until I approached the counter.  Ordered my food and was given a tray with a number on it, cafeteria style.  Now, the food, that has not changed.  And that is not a bad thing one bit.  I loved what I had and what was always my go to item here.  I got the General Tso's Chicken and a vegetable roll.  They sure do give you a lot of food, so much so that I took about half of it with me on the way out the door.  Not too spicy, and it filled my gut with some warmth.  I absolutely love the vegetable rolls they have here.  And what makes them better is combo sauce they give you.  I know it's nothing more than duck sauce with hot mustard dropped in it, but for some reason it's what makes the vegetable roll so much better.  Customer service needs a little work here.  I am also concerned that this place may not be here much longer, it's a bit deserted at times.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. General Tso chicken and vegetable roll.

7mfkxzLhqiZ90tFSjLLC-Q.text: I haven't been to Lulu's in years. I used to visit there all the time when I worked and went to school in Oakland.   We were in the area and stopped and it wasn't the same LuLus I remembered. We both ordered vegetable egg rolls, but when they arrived, they were still frozen inside.   They added mustard to the duck sauce which we personally don't care for.   I went specifically for Singapore Rice noodles, which online still showed that they offered, so I was disappointed when it was no longer offered.   I got the Pad Thai, which was good and my bf got the crispy fried noodles which wasn't what he expected, but it was good.   The service was quick and friendly, the prices were reasonable and it was fun to return to an old favorite place.

leE4HYzdoB0ASiNNYf5Iiw.text: I just had my first Lulu's and I think that three stars is pretty accurate overall for the experience I had.   First of all, the convenience is awesome. You can order on Tapingo and pay with Panther Funds, which is a great way to save a few bucks -- or at least not spend any money you haven't already set aside. I ordered on the app and my order was ready in less than ten minutes, and since I live close the total time between my order and taking a bite was less than twenty minutes. Can't beat that.  The actual food is good but leaves some things to be desired. I ordered the Hong Kong Chow Fun, and the noodles were awesome -- panfried, chewy, carby deliciousness. Exactly what I wanted. The green onions and regular onions were perfectly cooked; the flavor was there but didn't overpower the overall dish's flavor. The only problem was the beef. It was ground beef, which I've never seen at a Chinese restaurant and it honestly skeeved me out a little bit. It still tasted fine (if a little chewy in places, as ground beef is wont to be), but based off of pictures I expected strips of beef which I'm much more used to. The portion size is GIANT. I was pretty freaking hungry and I still couldn't finish it, which is great since my goal as a college student is to stretch every meal eaten out into two.  I also ordered a black bubble tea with taro flavoring and no milk. They were out of regular boba so I believe I was given popping lychee boba instead. This was still fine -- I've never tried the popping boba before but I didn't mind it. However, the actual tea is just kind of lackluster. Also it was greyish, which is pretty unappealing. It looked a bit like I was drinking dirty dishwater. That being said, it's not the worst bubble tea I've ever had and I'm drinking it no problem.  Overall, Lulu's is a convenient student eatery with good prices, but the cutting corners behind those deals is apparent in some places. The huge portion sizes make it worth it to come here every so often, but it's far from the best Chinese in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Taro-flavored assam black tea with no milk and popping lychee boba.
Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hong Kong chow fun with ground beef. Note that the beef is ground, not in strips.

eCzfGI8hEYjzmavT6Y6MhQ.text: Many friends told me they loved this place so I decided to stop for lunch. Ugh.  I opted for the Earth ramen soup, veggie broth, veggies, dumplings and a veggie egg roll. The egg roll was good but very salty. The broth in the soup was spicy, I like spicy but wasn't expecting it as the menu didn't state anything about it. Otherwise, there wasn't much flavor to the broth. The veggies were bland and I think the dumplings were just tofu.  My friend got a rice bowl and wasn't thrilled either.  The place was also dingy and the area behind the counter was dirty. Sadly, I won't be going back.

gw0YvywfpWzqirtNMUq3PQ.text: I've been coming here for 20 years. They have recently changed the menu (menu on Yelp is old) and have changed for the worse. They used to have only one kind of delicious Ramen noodle soup with miso broth, now they have five different kinds of Ramen noodle soup all with pork broth, spicy pork broth or vegetable broth. It is not at all the same ramen noodle soup. Other items on the menu are also completely different. If you are reading this Lulu's management, please go back to the way you've successfully been running your business for the past 20 years and get rid of this new menu.

Pt1CKo2D4Wcc2kmD4CoITQ.text: Food was DELICIOUS. Quiet, good atmosphere, interesting menu. Wish the water cups were a bit bigger but that's a minor thing. Will be coming again.

photos.caption: Photo of Lulu's Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spicy Basil with Chicken

3RBZ0sA9jiLnbWokHA5P8w.text: Noodles taste like cardboard and lack flavor. I got the lard na noodles and was utterly disappointed. There's so many better noodle places in Pittsburgh, it's a shame to serve food this poor in quality. Here's to hoping that Craig street gets better noodle places in the near future. Unless you're starving in a zombie apocalypse and this is the only place open, I would avoid it.

WqfraD8xlle3QEeBEUWymA.text: Oh Lulu's...what happened? You have been so awesome for so many years and my last meal this weekend was just sad. You were one of my go to's for pad thai and tom yum soup. The soup was good but the pad thai was not as awesome as I remembered it to be. I used to order flats of pad thai to serve at parties I loved it so much. This time, it tasted lacking and bland. The Korean bi bim bap with beef not as good as at Korean food only restaurants, more like the fast food version with ground beef and hard boiled egg.   I think it's time to shake out the sheets and freshen the whole place up. The location is great and service is fast. The pictures on the walls I thought so cool are now faded and need to be updated, much like the weird dance club music from the '90s you insisted on blasting at 11 am.    Your prices are still great and I don't want to give up on you after all these years, but after my last trip there, I'm in no hurry to go back and will be sure to read recent Yelp reviews before I return. Good luck. I'm rooting for you.
